title: Milan-Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics: A Global Sports Spectacle
summary: The Milan-Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics are set to begin in Italy, featuring approximately 2,900 athletes from more than 90 nations competing across snow and ice disciplines for 16 days. The event is spread across multiple venues in northern Italy, including Milan, Cortina d'Ampezzo, Predazzo, Tesero, Livigno, and Bormio, highlighting the region's diverse landscapes. The opening ceremony on Friday at Milan's San Siro stadium will include performances by artists like Mariah Carey and Andrea Bocelli, with additional ceremonies in Cortina and other locations to accommodate the dispersed venues. Great Britain's team, led by flag-bearers Lilah Fear and Brad Hall, aims to surpass its previous best of five medals, with UK Sport projecting up to eight medals. BBC coverage provides extensive access, with live broadcasts starting from the opening ceremony. This Olympics not only showcases athletic excellence but also explores Great Britain's emerging status in winter sports despite limited natural ice and snow conditions.

background_read: The Winter Olympics is a major international multi-sport event held every four years, featuring competitions in snow and ice sports like skiing, skating, and bobsleigh. The 2026 edition in Milan-Cortina represents Italy's third time hosting the Winter Games, following Cortina d'Ampezzo in 1956 and Turin in 2006. The event promotes global unity and athletic achievement, with countries investing in training programs to improve medal counts. Great Britain's involvement has grown despite its temperate climate, thanks to initiatives like UK Sport funding. The BBC's role as a broadcaster ensures wide accessibility, highlighting the cultural and economic impact of the Olympics on host regions and viewers worldwide.
